edge: 12 Years a Slave is a biographical drama film based on the memoir Twelve Years a Slave by Solomon Northup, who was kidnapped and sold into slavery for 12 years.
Solomon Northup was kidnapped in Washington, D.C. By two conmen in 1841 and sold into slavery.

McQueen undercuts Christianity itself as well, in an effort to update the ethical lessons from Northup's story for the 21st century, by holding the institutions of Christianity up to the light for their ability to justify slavery at the time.

In Northup's own words, "There never was a more kind, noble, candid, Christian man than William Ford," adding that Ford's circumstances "blinded [Ford] to the inherent wrong at the bottom of the system of Slavery."

Northup was a Christian of his time, writing of his former master being "blinded" by "circumstances"[26] that in retrospect meant a racist acceptance of slavery despite being a Christian, a position untenable to Christians now[28] and to Christian abolitionists of the 19th century but not contradictory to Northup himself.
Forrest Wickman of Slate wrote of Northup's book giving a more favorable account of the author's onetime master, William Ford,
According to Wickman, "the McQueen film" frequently undermines Ford.

After meeting screenwriter John Ridley at a Creative Artists Agency screening of Hunger in 2008, director Steve McQueen got in touch with Ridley about his interest in making a film about 'the slave era in America' with 'a character that was not obvious in terms of their trade in slavery.' This idea developed back and forth until McQueen's partner, Bianca Stigter, found Solomon Northup's 1853 memoir Twelve Years a Slave. This discovery led McQueen to say in an interview that 'the two did not strike a chord until [this moment].'
Solomon Northup's 1853 memoir Twelve Years a Slave served as the source material for McQueen and Ridley's film.

McQueen explained that the filmmakers used an earth-toned color palette to accurately depict the time period of the film and collaborated with costume designer Patricia Norris, who compiled nearly 1,000 historically accurate costumes for the film. Norris took earth samples from all three of the plantations to match the clothes and had conversations with Sean Bobbitt about dealing with the character temperature on each plantation, highlighting the minute detail put into this aspect of the production.

McQueen explained that the filmmakers drew visual comparisons to the works of Spanish painter Francisco Goya in their filming approach, choosing not to adopt the desaturated visual style typical of a more gritty documentary aesthetic.

node_2: horrendous pictures of violence and torture
edge: McQueen explained that Goya's amazing and exquisite paintings of violence and torture were depicted accurately in the film because the visuals were drawn from his works, and if they had been painted poorly or put in the wrong perspective, it would have drawn more attention to what was wrong with the image rather than looking at the images.
The filmmakers conducted extensive research that included studying artwork from the era in order to create historically accurate costumes for the film.

The film, '12 Years a Slave', earned a total of $187.7 million worldwide.
In the United States, '12 Years a Slave' grossed $56.7 million.
'12 Years a Slave' had its opening limited release in the United States, earning $923,715 on 19 screens.
'12 Years a Slave' entered the top ten rankings after expanding to 123 theatres and grossing an additional $2.1 million.
The film release was expanded to over 1,100 locations on November 8, 2013.
Rotten Tomatoes reports that 95% of critics gave '12 Years a Slave' a positive rating.
The site's consensus states, 'It's far from comfortable viewing, but 12 Years a Slave's unflinchingly brutal look at American slavery is also brilliant – and quite possibly essential – cinema.'
'12 Years a Slave' received positive reviews from 379 critics on Rotten Tomatoes.
'12 Years a Slave' has an average score of 96 out of 100 on Metacritic, based on 57 reviews from mainstream critics.
'12 Years a Slave' received an 'A' grade from CinemaScore, indicating positive feedback from audiences.

Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times that the genius of 12 Years a Slave is its insistence on banal evil, and on terror, that seeped into souls, bound bodies and reaped an enduring, terrible price.

The Daily Telegraph's Tim Robey granted the film a maximum score of five stars, stating that 'it's the nobility of this remarkable film that pierces the soul', while praising Ejiofor and Nyong'o's performances.

Tina Hassannia of Slant Magazine said that 'using his signature visual composition and deafening sound design, Steve McQueen portrays the harrowing realism of Northup's experience and the complicated relationships between master and slave, master and master, slave and slave, and so on'.

David Simon, the creator of the TV series The Wire, highly praised the movie, commenting that 'it marks the first time in history that our entertainment industry, albeit with international creative input, has managed to stare directly at slavery and maintain that gaze'.

Stephanie Zacharek of The Village Voice stated that the film 'stays more than a few safe steps away from anything so dangerous as raw feeling' and 'never compromises its aesthetic purity' when depicting inhuman cruelty.

Peter Malamud Smith of Slate criticized the story of '12 Years a Slave', stating that it 'offers every viewer a way into empathizing with its protagonist' and that 'we're more invested in one hero than in millions of victims; if we're forced to imagine ourselves enslaved, we want to imagine ourselves as Northup, a special person who miraculously escaped the system that attempted to crush him.'
Ignatiy Vishnevetsky of The A.V. Club opined that director Steve McQueen is 'essentially tone-deaf when it comes to performance' and that the film 'lacks a necessary emotional continuity.'

McQueen's movie is structured around an ending that is supposed to function as a release, but because it cannot organize the sense of catharsis it so badly needs, it just feels like McQueen is scurrying for an exit.
[103] The reviewer states that the cast is wildly uneven.

Critics identified 12 Years a Slave as an example of the white savior narrative in film. Doubts still lingered about its ability to truly bring about a newfound racial consciousness among a national, mainstream audience. Brad Pitt's character served as a 'white savior.'

node_2: its ability to truly bring about a newfound racial consciousness among a national, mainstream audience
edge: Critics identified 12 Years a Slave as an example of the white savior narrative in film. Doubts still lingered about its ability to truly bring about a newfound racial consciousness among a national, mainstream audience.
The film also was a period piece that featured a happy ending.

Black Canadian author Orville Lloyd Douglas said he would not be seeing 12 Years a Slave, explaining: 'I'm convinced these black race films are created for a white, liberal film audience to engender white guilt and make them feel bad about themselves. Regardless of your race, these films are unlikely to teach you anything you don't already know.'

A Black writer, Michael Arceneaux, wrote a rebuttal essay 'We Don't Need To Get Over Slavery... Or Movies About Slavery'. Arceneaux criticized Douglas for being ignorant and having an apathetic attitude towards black Americans and slavery.
The film, '12 Years a Slave', received the prestigious award of 'Best Picture' at the Academy Awards.
The screenplay for '12 Years a Slave' was recognized with the award for 'Best Adapted Screenplay' at the Academy Awards.
Lupita Nyong'o, who played an important role in '12 Years a Slave', won the award for 'Best Supporting Actress' at the Academy Awards.
